Produce more by removing more.  

Aristotle talked about three kinds of work.  

In our modern world, we emphasize only two.  

The first is theoretical work.  

The end goal of theoretical work is truth.  

The second is practical work.  

The objective of practical work is action.  

But there is a third type: poietical work.  

The philosopher Martin Heidegger described poiesis as a “bringing-forth.”  

This third type of work is the Essentialist way.  

An Essentialist produces more by removing more.  

We often don’t take time to think about our efforts.  

We need to identify which efforts will produce results.  

It is easier to think of execution in terms of addition.  

If we want to sell more products, we get more salespeople.  

If we want to produce more output, we ramp up production.  

There is evidence to support this approach.  

However, there is another way to improve results.  

Instead of adding efforts, the Essentialist removes constraints.  

But how do we do this?  

Be clear about the essential intent.  

We can’t know what to remove without a clear outcome.  

When we don’t know our goal, all change is arbitrary.  

So ask yourself, “How will we know when we are done?”
